sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis: 320 mg ORALLY once a day for 5 days
  • Community acquired pneumonia: 320 mg ORALLY once a day for 5 to 7 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy in children less than 18 years of age have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: CrCl greater than 40 mL/min, usual dose; CrCl 40 mL/min or less, 160 mg every 24 hr
  • hemodialysis, continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: 160 mg every 24 hr
  • hepatic impairment: mild, moderate or severe (Child-Pugh Class A, B or C), no dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis
  • Community acquired pneumonia

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Fluoroquinolones, including gemifloxacin mesylate, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. Risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart, or lung transplants. Fluoroquinolones, including gemifloxacin mesylate, may exacerbate muscle weakness in persons with myasthenia gravis. Avoid in patients with known history of myasthenia gravis.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to gemifloxacin or any product component, or other fluoroquinolones

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• myasthenia gravis; may exacerbate muscle weakness; ventilatory support requirement and death have been reported; avoid use
  • tendinitis and tendon rupture, increased risk; risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart or lung transplant; discontinue therapy at first sign of tendon pain, swelling or inflammation
  • central nervous system disorders such as epilepsy or predisposition to convulsions; may increase risk of seizures or lower the seizure threshold
  • concomitant use of Class IA (eg, procainamide, quinidine) or Class III antiarrhythmic agents (eg, amiodarone, sotalol) or other medications that prolong the QT interval should be avoided
  • elderly at greater risk of QT prolongation
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, have been reported
  • hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, uncorrected, may increase risk of QT interval prolongation; use not recommended
  • pediatric patients; safety and efficacy not established
  • peripheral neuropathy has been reported with oral and injectable fluoroquinolones; may occur any time during therapy and persist for months to years or become permanent even after discontinuation; if symptoms occur, discontinue use and switch to a non-fluoroquinolone unless benefit outweighs risk
  • phototoxicity, may occur with excessive exposure to sunlight; discontinue if phototoxicity occurs
  • physical activity, strenuous; may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • pregnancy, nursing mothers; safety and efficacy not established
  • proarrhythmic conditions, ongoing, such as bradycardia or acute myocardial ischemia; may increase risk of QT interval prolongation
  • renal impairment (creatinine clearance 40 mL/min or less); dosage adjustment recommended
  • renal failure; may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • QT interval prolongation, history of; risk of torsade de pointes; use not recommended
  • tendon disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, history of; may increase risk of tendon rupture

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Gemifloxacin: Micromedex: Infant risk has been demonstrated.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (3.5%.)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (2.2%.), Diarrhea (5%), Nausea (3.7%.), Vomiting (1.6%.)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (1.7%.), Headache (4.2%.)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval
  • Musculoskeletal:Myasthenia gravis, Exacerbation, Rupture of tendon, Tendinitis
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Gemifloxacin mesylate is a fluoroquinolone bactericidal drug with a wide-spectrum of activity against Gram-negative and Gram positive microorganisms. It blocks the essential components for bacterial growth, DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV (TOPO IV), which results in the inhibition of DNA synthesis.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 0.5 h to 2 h
  • Bioavailability: 71%
  • Effect of food: none

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: 4.18 L/kg (1.66 L/kg to 12.12 L/kg)
  • Protein binding: approximately 60% to 70%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic; limited extent
  • Major metabolites: N-acetyl gemifloxacin, E-isomer of gemifloxacin and carbamyl glucuronide of gemifloxacin

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 61% +/- 9.5%
  • Renal: 36% +/- 9.3% as unchanged and metabolites
  • Dialyzable: yes (hemodialysis), 20% to 30% removed

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • take with or without food; swallow whole, do not chew
  • should not be given with dairy products (ie, milk or yogurt) or calcium-fortified juices alone; may be given with meals containing these
  • if given together, take antacids containing aluminum or magnesium at least 3 hours before or 2 hours after the dose
  • if given together, take ferrous sulfate (iron) at least 3 hours before or 2 hours after the dose
  • if given together, take multivitamins with zinc at least 3 hours before or 2 hours after the dose
  • if given together, take didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution at least 3 hours before or 2 hours after the dose
  • if given together, take at least 2 hours before sucralfate

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report symptoms of tendonitis or tendon rupture (pain, swelling, inflammation of tendon), especially if elderly and/or using concomitant steroids.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, including pain, burning, tingling, or numbness.
  • Advise patient to avoid tanning beds and to use sunscreen, protective clothing, and hats, as drug is phototoxic.
  • Tell patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness or somnolence.
  • Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, urticaria, rash, or headaches.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of QT prolongation (tachycardia, loss of consciousness) or persistent diarrhea (bloody/watery stools).
  • Tell patient to maintain adequate hydration and to avoid milk, yogurt, or calcium-fortified juices alone with drug. Drug may be taken with meals that contain these products.
  • Instruct patient to take magnesium or aluminum-containing antacids, didanosine (buffered tablets or powder for oral solution), or products containing iron or zinc at least 3 hours before or 2 hours after drug.
  • Warn patient to take drug at least 2 hours before sucralfate.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult doctor prior to new drug use, including over-the-counter and herbal drugs.
